prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Epoch 1
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: First epoch of Sgr A* Band 3 polarization observations. This epoch is 3 hours in duration, the minimum time required for polarization observations.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We have requested the standard correlator setup for continuum polarimetric observations, which is perfectly adequate for our observation. More specifically, for Sgr A* in Band 3, the expected Faraday rotation of the polarization position angle across the full 16 GHz bandwidth is ~100 degrees, but the rotation across a 31 MHz channel is only 0.2 degrees.

Sgr A* has a scatter-broadened size of only ~0.25 milliarcseconds at 100 GHz so is effectively pointlike. However, to effectively filter contaminating emission, our observations should utilize any configurations except C36-1 and C36-2 (with 3.4'' and 1.8'' resolution, respectively).

This science goal seeks to measure the linear polarization of Sgr A* in Band 3 as well as its variation with frequency from Faraday rotation. Sgr A* is very bright (~2 Jy), and past observations suggest that the linear polarization fraction may be as high as 2% at these frequencies. As a result, integrations as short as ~2 minutes would provide excellent precision for the polarization measurements within each IF. Because Sgr A* is highly variable, especially in its polarization, these observations will be able to track intrahour variability of the source and of the rotation measure, which is expected to cause a ~300 degree wrap in the polarization position angle across the full 16 GHz bandwidth.
Our measurements will likely be limited by systematic uncertainties remaining after polarimetric calibration, especially in the relative calibration between IFs. To determine this relative calibration as accurately as possible, observations on pointlike calibrators that do not have high rotation measure (e.g., J1921-293 and J1733-130) would be beneficial. We understand that this is standard calibration for polarization observations, and that the calibrator will be chosen automatically from the list maintained by ALMA staff.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Epoch 2

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Epoch 3
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Third epoch of Sgr A* Band 3 polarization observations. This epoch is 3 hours in duration, the minimum time required for polarization observations.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We have requested the standard correlator setup for continuum polarimetric observations, which is perfectly adequate for our observation. More specifically, for Sgr A* in Band 3, the expected Faraday rotation of the polarization position angle across the full 16 GHz bandwidth is ~100 degrees, but the rotation across a 31 MHz channel is only 0.2 degrees.

Sgr A* has a scatter-broadened size of only ~0.25 milliarcseconds at 100 GHz so is effectively pointlike. However, to effectively filter contaminating emission, our observations should utilize any configurations except C36-1 and C36-2 (with 3.4'' and 1.8'' resolution, respectively).

This science goal seeks to measure the linear polarization of Sgr A* in Band 3 as well as its variation with frequency from Faraday rotation. Sgr A* is very bright (~2 Jy), and past observations suggest that the linear polarization fraction may be as high as 2% at these frequencies. prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: The Galactic Center supermassive black hole, Sagittarius A* (Sgr A*), is vastly underluminous, emitting nine orders of magnitude below its Eddington luminosity and providing an important prototype of the ubiquitous class of low luminosity galactic nuclei. The polarization of Sgr A* has been a particularly important guide for theories of its accretion and emission, and Band 3 polarimetry with ALMA provides an essential addition to these studies, probing a transition regime of the flow where the linear polarization drops sharply and the emission size grows steeply with decreasing frequency. The unprecedented sensitivity of ALMA will permit the first unambiguous estimate of the rotation measure of Sgr A* at ~100 GHz, will precisely measure the linear polarization fraction at this frequency, and will track the evolution of each on timescales from months to minutes, reflecting the magnetic field structure and dynamics throughout the accretion flow on scales from thousands of Schwarzschild radii to the event horizon.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:previousProposals: 2013.1.00764.S, "Probing Accretion Flow Dynamics of Sgr A* on Scales from 1 to 1000 Schwarzschild Radii with ALMA Polarimetry", PI: Geoffrey Bower
